translated: Jātaka
Book of Twenties
The Chapter on Mātaṅga
The Sattigumba Jātaka
The great king, the hunter,
the lord of the five-hundred chariots,
went out with his army
and entered the forest without a guide.
There he saw in the forest
a hut made by the Takkaras;
from that hut
a young man was speaking to the hunters.
“A man with a complete chariot,
a young man with earrings well-placed,
shines with a red turban,
shining like the sun in the day.
At midday,
the king and charioteer are asleep;
let us take all his ornaments
by force.
Even at night, now,
the king and charioteer are asleep;
taking his clothes and jeweled earrings,
let us kill him with branches and cover him up.”
“Why are you speaking like this,
Sattigumba, as if you’re insane?
Kings are hard to approach,
like a blazing fire.”
“But you, a mere husband,
are roaring so arrogantly!
My mother is naked,
Why do you want to turn back?”
“Rise up, my friend, quickly,
harness the chariot, charioteer;
I do not like this bird,
we will go to another hermitage.”
“The chariot is harnessed, great king,
and it is strong and powerful;
Take control, great king,
we will go to another hermitage.”
“Who are all those who have gone,
who were my attendants here?
This Pañcāla is going,
freed from their sight.
Take up your swords,
spears and javelins;
This Pañcāla is going,
do not let him escape with his life!”
Then another one welcomed him,
Suva the red-tufted one;
“Welcome to you, great king,
and you have not come from far away;
You are the lord who has arrived,
whatever is here tell me.
There are tinduka fruits, piyal fruits,
madhuka fruits and kāsumāri fruits;
There are small fruits,
eat them, king, the best of the best.
This is cool water,
brought from the mountain caves;
Drink from it, great king,
if you so desire.

analyzed: araññam uñchāya gatā  ye asmin paricārakā
translated: “Those who are my companions,🔽who have gone to the forest for alms,
you should get up and gather them,
I have no hands to give alms.”
“Excellent indeed is this bird,
the one who is supremely righteous;
But this other bird,
the young one, speaks like a hunter.
‘Kill him, bind him,
don’t let him go free!’
While he was lamenting like this,
I have reached safety in the hermitage.”
“We are brothers, great king,
born of the same mother,
we grew up in the same tree,
but we went to different fields.
The sattigumba is for the thieves,
and I am here for the seers.
He is bad, I am good,
by that quality we are not the same.”
“There, killing, binding,
cheating, and deceit,
plundering, and violence,
that’s what he trains in there.

original: Idha saccañca dhammo ca,🔽Ahiṁsā saṁyamo damo;🔽Āsanūdakadāyīnaṁ,
analyzed: idha saccañca dhammo ca  ahisā sayamaḥ damaḥ  āsanūdaka dāyīna
translated: Here, truth and righteousness,🔽non-violence, restraint, and self-control,🔽I was raised on the lap
of those who give seats and water, Bhāradvāja.”
“Whatever a king associates with,
whether good or bad,
and with whomsoever one associates,🔽he becomes like that,
for association makes for likeness.🔽One who associates with one who associates,
who touches one who touches another,🔽like a wet cow-dung cake
sticks to the other;

but the wise man, fearing contact,🔽does not make a wicked man his friend.🔽The man who with the tip of a blade of grass🔽should try to draw up water from the bottom of the sea,🔽the blade of grass would rot,
so is the result of associating with fools.
The man who with a handful of flowers🔽should try to perfume a whole wood,
